templates.name: grateful
templates.angle: Express genuine appreciation for their contribution to science. Position Ouro as a way to amplify the impact of work you're thankful exists.
templates.subject_line_style: Lead with thanks or appreciation to the pursuit of knowledge.

templates.name: peer
templates.angle: Write as a fellow computational researcher who shares joy to be working on what they love. You're not pitchingâ€”you're sharing joy and sharing what you've built.
templates.subject_line_style: Informal, like an email between colleagues. Can reference shared tools, methods, or pain points.

templates.name: curious
templates.angle: Lead with genuine intellectual curiosity about their specific approach. Ask or wonder about something in their abstract before introducing Ouro.
templates.subject_line_style: Frame as a question or express interest in a specific aspect of their work.

templates.name: impact
templates.angle: Frame around legacy and reach. Their work deserves to be used, not just cited. Ouro helps their tools outlive the paper.
templates.subject_line_style: Focus on reach, longevity, or their work being used. Slightly provocative is okay.

templates.name: broader-impacts
templates.angle: Acknowledge the importance of their NSF-funded work reaching beyond academia. Ouro makes it easy to demonstrate real-world use and accessibility for grant reports.
templates.subject_line_style: Reference impact, accessibility, or public benefit of their research.
templates.pi_motivation: NSF requirements, grant reporting, broader impacts checkbox

templates.name: students
templates.angle: Focus on how Ouro benefits their grad students and postdocs. Publishing tools builds their reputation before they're on the job market. A student's tool getting used by other labs is a powerful career asset.
templates.subject_line_style: Reference their group, lab, or training the next generation.
templates.pi_motivation: student careers, lab reputation, legacy through mentees

templates.name: citations
templates.angle: Their datasets and tools deserve to be cited, not just used invisibly. Ouro makes their computational work citable and trackable.
templates.subject_line_style: Reference getting credit, citations, or recognition for computational work.

templates.name: offload
templates.angle: Position Ouro as the answer to 'code available upon request.' No more fielding emails, no more digging up old scripts. Put it on Ouro once, point people there forever.
templates.subject_line_style: Reference making their work accessible without the hassle.

ouro_descriptions.content: I'm building Ouro, a platform where computational researchers publish working tools (datasets, analysis scripts, APIs) that others can plug directly into their own workflows. Less time recreating methods from papers, more time on the actual science.
I'm building Ouro, a platform for sharing computational tools and datasets in a way that's actually usable, not just a zip file in supplementary materials.

I'm building Ouro, a place to publish your computational workflows as APIs with a Python SDK so other researchers can call your methods directly. Your work becomes infrastructure others build on, not just a paper they cite.

I'm building Ouro, where researchers publish datasets and computational tools as APIs that others can actually use, not just read about in a methods section. Your group's work becomes discoverable and citable.
I'm working on Ouro, which helps researchers share computational work (workflows, datasets, notebooks) in a way that's actually reproducible and discoverable by others in your field.
